medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left carpal tunnel syndrome. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left carpal tunnel syndrome. OPERATIVE PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Left carpal tunnel release. FINDINGS: Showed severe compression of the median nerve on the left at the wrist. SPECIMENS: None. FLUIDS: 500 mL of crystalloids. URINE OUTPUT: No Foley catheter. COMPLICATIONS: None. ANESTHESIA: General through a laryngeal mask. ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: None. CONDITION: Resuscitated with stable vital signs. INDICATION FOR THE OPERATION: This is a case of a very pleasant 65-year-old forensic pathologist who I previously had performed initially a discectomy and removal of infection at 6-7, followed by anterior cervical discectomy with anterior interbody fusion at C5-6 and C6-7 with spinal instrumentation. At the time of initial consultation, the patient was also found to have bilateral carpal tunnel and for which we are addressing the left side now. Operation, expected outcome, risks, and benefits were discussed with him for most of the risk would be that of infection because of the patient's diabetes and a previous history of infection in the form of pneumonia. There is also the possibility of bleeding as well as the possibility of injury to the median nerve on dissection. He understood this risk and agreed to have the procedure performed. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROCEDURE: The patient was brought to the operating room, awake, alert, not in any form of distress. After smooth induction of anesthesia and placement of a laryngeal mask, he remained supine on the operating table. The left upper extremity was then prepped with Betadine soap and antiseptic solution. After sterile drapes were laid out, an incision was made following inflation of blood pressure cuff to 250 mmHg. Clamp time approximately 30 minutes. An incision was then made right in the mid palm area between the thenar and hypothenar eminence. Meticulous hemostasis of any bleeders were done. The fat was identified. The palmar aponeurosis was identified and cut and this was traced down to the wrist. There was severe compression of the median nerve. Additional removal of the aponeurosis was performed to allow for further decompression. After this was all completed, the area was irrigated with saline and bacitracin solution and closed as a single layer using Prolene 4-0 as interrupted vertical mattress stitches. Dressing was applied. The patient was brought to the recovery.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left carpal tunnel syndrome.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left carpal tunnel syndrome.  
OPERATIVE PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Left carpal tunnel release.  

FINDINGS: The median nerve on the left wrist was severely compressed.  

SPECIMENS: None.  
FLUIDS: 500 mL of crystalloid solution.  
URINE OUTPUT: No Foley catheter.  
COMPLICATIONS: None.  
ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia delivered through a laryngeal mask.  
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: None.  
CONDITION: The patient was stabilized and had normal vital signs.  

INDICATION FOR THE OPERATION:  
The patient is a 65‑year‑old forensic pathologist who previously had a discectomy and infection removal at levels 6‑7, followed by an anterior cervical discectomy and fusion at C5‑6 and C6‑7 with spinal instrumentation. He also has carpal tunnel syndrome on both hands, and this surgery addresses the left side. The risks discussed included infection (due to his diabetes and a past pneumonia infection), bleeding, and possible injury to the median nerve. He understood these risks and agreed to the procedure.  

DESCRIPTION OF THE PROCEDURE:  
The patient was taken to the operating room, awake and alert, and was not in distress. After anesthesia was smoothly started and a laryngeal mask was placed, he lay on his back on the operating table. The left hand was cleaned with Betadine and antiseptic solution. Sterile drapes were applied, and an incision was made while the blood pressure cuff was inflated to 250 mmHg. The clamp time was about 30 minutes. The incision was made in the middle of the palm, between the thumb and little finger areas. Bleeding was carefully controlled. Fat tissue was identified, and the palmar aponeurosis was cut and followed down to the wrist. The median nerve was found to be severely compressed. Additional removal of the aponeurosis was done to relieve pressure. The area was washed with saline and bacitracin solution, then closed with a single layer of Prolene 4‑0 interrupted vertical mattress stitches. A dressing was applied. The patient was taken to recovery.
